Message.Issue:
'AspNetUser.AspNetUser()' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
AspNetUser..ctor() AspNetUser.set_ProductSubscriptions(ICollection<ProductSubscription>):Void

'AspNetUser.AspNetUser()' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
AspNetUser..ctor() AspNetUser.set_UserProductNotifiations(ICollection<UserProductNotifiation>):Void

'AspNetUser.AspNetUser()' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
AspNetUser..ctor() AspNetUser.set_UserProductNotifications(ICollection<UserProductNotification>):Void

'Category.Category()' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
Category..ctor() Category.set_Products(ICollection<Product>):Void

'Product.Product()' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
Product..ctor() Product.set_ProductNotifications(ICollection<ProductNotification>):Void

'Product.Product()' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
Product..ctor() Product.set_ProductSubscriptions(ICollection<ProductSubscription>):Void

'ProductNotification.ProductNotification()' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
ProductNotification..ctor() ProductNotification.set_UserProductNotifiations(ICollection<UserProductNotifiation>):Void

'ProductNotification.ProductNotification()' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
ProductNotification..ctor() ProductNotification.set_UserProductNotifications(ICollection<UserProductNotification>):Void

Implement IDisposable on 'UnitOfWork' because it creates members of the following IDisposable types: 'EFDBEntities', 'ReadEFDBEntities'. If 'UnitOfWork' has previously shipped, adding new members that implement IDisposable to this type is considered a breaking change to existing consumers.

Make 'HardCodedProductRepository' sealed (a breaking change if this class has previously shipped), implement the method non-explicitly, or implement a new method that exposes the functionality of 'IProductRepository.GetProductById(int?)' and is visible to derived classes.

Implement IDisposable on 'NotificationRepository' because it creates members of the following IDisposable types: 'EFDBEntities'. If 'NotificationRepository' has previously shipped, adding new members that implement IDisposable to this type is considered a breaking change to existing consumers.

Rule.Name: Collection properties should be read only
Rule.Description: Properties that return collections should be read-only so that users cannot entirely replace the backing store. Users can still modify the contents of the collection by calling relevant methods on the collection. Note that the XmlSerializer class has special support for deserializing read-only collections. See the XmlSerializer overview for more information.

Rule.Name: Do not call overridable methods in constructors
Rule.Description: Virtual methods defined on the class should not be called from constructors. If a derived class has overridden the method, the derived class version will be called (before the derived class constructor is called).
Rule.Resolution: {0} contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences: {1}

Rule.Name: Interface methods should be callable by child types
Rule.Description: Explicit method implementations are defined with private accessibility. Classes that derive from classes with explicit method implementations and choose to re-declare them on the class will not be able to call into the base class implementation unless the base class has provided an alternate method with appropriate accessibility. When overriding a base class method that has been hidden by explicit interface implementation, in order to call into the base class implementation, a derived class must cast the base pointer to the relevant interface. When calling through this reference, however, the derived class implementation will actually be invoked, resulting in recursion and an eventual stack overflow.
Rule.Resolution: Make {0} sealed (a breaking change if this class has previously shipped), implement the method non-explicitly, or implement a new method that exposes the functionality of {1} and is visible to derived classes.

Rule.Name: Types that own disposable fields should be disposable
Rule.Description: Types that declare disposable members should also implement IDisposable. If the type does not own any unmanaged resources, do not implement a finalizer on it.
Rule.Resolution: Implement IDisposable on {0} because it creates members of the following IDisposable types: {1}. If {0} has previously shipped, adding new members that implement IDisposable to this type is considered a breaking change to existing consumers.
